channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07255-w

The molecular basis of sugar detection by an insect taste receptor

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07227-0

A recently quenched galaxy 700 million years after the Big Bang

item.title: These tiny fish combine electric pulses to probe the environment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00685-6

Elephantnose fish share electric pulses to extend their senses, and the bumblebees that show a uniquely human trait.
item.dc:title: These tiny fish combine electric pulses to probe the environment
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Bumblebees show unique human behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00669-6

The bees learn how to complete a two-step puzzle too complex to solve independently, by watching other bees.
item.dc:title: Bumblebees show unique human behaviour
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: Integrated optical frequency division for microwave and mmWave generation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07057-0

A miniaturized optical frequency division system that could transfer the generation of microwaves, with superior spectral purity, to a complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor-compatible integrated photonic platform is demonstrated showing potential for large-volume, low-cost manufacturing for many applications.
item.dc:title: Integrated optical frequency division for microwave and mmWave generation
item.dc:creator: Shuman Sun
Beichen Wang
Kaikai Liu

Andreas Beling

Xu Yi

item.title: A rapidly time-varying equatorial jet in Jupiter’s deep interior
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07046-3

An axisymmetric, equatorial jet in Jupiter’s interior has a wavelike fluctuation with a 4-year period, revealing hidden aspects of the magnetic field within the metallic hydrogen region and constraining the dynamo that generates the magnetic field.
item.dc:title: A rapidly time-varying equatorial jet in Jupiter’s deep interior
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Bloxham
Hao Cao
David J. Stevenson
John E. P. Connerney
Scott J. Bolton

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07000-9

Reply to: Model uncertainty obscures major driver of soil carbon
item.dc:title: Reply to: Model uncertainty obscures major driver of soil carbon

item.title: Collective sensing in electric fish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07157-x

Through modelling, neural recordings and behavioural experiments, a study shows that individual electric fish use electrical pulses of conspecifics to extend their electrolocation range, discriminate objects and increase information transmission.
item.dc:title: Collective sensing in electric fish
item.dc:creator: Federico Pedraja
Nathaniel B. Sawtell

item.title: Photonic chip-based low-noise microwave oscillator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07058-z

We leverage advances in integrated photonics to generate low-noise microwaves with an optical frequency division architecture that can be low power and chip integrated.
item.dc:title: Photonic chip-based low-noise microwave oscillator
item.dc:creator: Igor Kudelin

item.title: Oxidative cyclization reagents reveal tryptophan cation–π interactions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07140-6

Global profiling of hyper-reactive tryptophan sites across whole proteomes using tryptophan chemical ligation by cyclization (Trp-CLiC) reveals a systematic map of tryptophan residues that participate in cation–π interactions, including functional sites that can regulate protein-mediated phase-separation processes.
item.dc:title: Oxidative cyclization reagents reveal tryptophan cation–π interactions
item.dc:creator: Xiao Xie

Christopher J. Chang

item.title: Genome-wide characterization of circulating metabolic biomarkers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07148-y

A meta-analysis of genome-wide association studies for 233 circulating metabolites from 33 cohorts reveals more than 400 loci and suggests probable causal genes, providing insights into metabolic pathways and disease aetiology.
item.dc:title: Genome-wide characterization of circulating metabolic biomarkers

item.title: The structure and physical properties of a packaged bacteriophage particle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07150-4

Multiresolution computational simulations generate all-atom models of a complete packaged virus particle.
item.dc:title: The structure and physical properties of a packaged bacteriophage particle
item.dc:creator: Kush Coshic
Christopher Maffeo
David Winogradoff
Aleksei Aksimentiev

item.title: Selfish conflict underlies RNA-mediated parent-of-origin effects
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07155-z

In Caenorhabditis tropicalis, selective expression of genetic alleles from one parent but not the other can arise from maternally inherited small transcripts acting via the PIWI-interacting RNA host defence pathway.
item.dc:title: Selfish conflict underlies RNA-mediated parent-of-origin effects
item.dc:creator: Pinelopi Pliota
Hana Marvanova
Alevtina Koreshova
Yotam Kaufman
Polina Tikanova
Daniel Krogull
Andreas Hagmüller
Sonya A. Widen
Dominik Handler
Joseph Gokcezade
Peter Duchek
Julius Brennecke
Eyal Ben-David
Alejandro Burga

item.title: Artificial intelligence and illusions of understanding in scientific research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07146-0

The proliferation of artificial intelligence tools in scientific research risks creating illusions of understanding, where scientists believe they understand more about the world than they actually do.
item.dc:title: Artificial intelligence and illusions of understanding in scientific research
item.dc:creator: Lisa Messeri
M. J. Crockett

item.title: Ultra-compact quasi-true time delay for boosting wireless channel capacity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07075-y

A quasi-true time delay is demonstrated for a microwave device implemented in a CMOS technology to miniaturize true-time-delay components of beam-steering systems, addressing the fundamental channel-capacity limitations and increasing data transmission in wireless communications.
item.dc:title: Ultra-compact quasi-true time delay for boosting wireless channel capacity
item.dc:creator: Bala Govind
Thomas Tapen
Alyssa Apsel

item.title: Universal recording of immune cell interactions in vivo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07134-4

A paper reports the development of a universal tool for studying cellular interactions in biological systems, and demonstrates its coupling with single-cell transcriptomics methods to provide insights into the biology of the interactions.
item.dc:title: Universal recording of immune cell interactions in vivo
item.dc:creator: Sandra Nakandakari-Higa
Sarah Walker
Maria C. C. Canesso
Verena van der Heide
Aleksey Chudnovskiy

item.title: Subicular neurons encode concave and convex geometries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07139-z

Longitudinal calcium imaging reveals the ability of corner cells to synchronize their activity with the environment, with the results implying the potential of the subiculum to contain the information required to reconstruct spatial environments.
item.dc:title: Subicular neurons encode concave and convex geometries
item.dc:creator: Yanjun Sun
Douglas A. Nitz
Xiangmin Xu
Lisa M. Giocomo

item.title: Decoding chromatin states by proteomic profiling of nucleosome readers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07141-5

A multidimensional proteomics analysis of the interactions between around 2,000 nuclear proteins and over 80 modified dinucleosomes representing promoter, enhancer and heterochromatin states provides insights into how chromatin states are decoded by chromatin readers.
item.dc:title: Decoding chromatin states by proteomic profiling of nucleosome readers
item.dc:creator: Saulius Lukauskas
Andrey Tvardovskiy
Nhuong V. Nguyen
Mara Stadler
Peter Faull
Tina Ravnsborg

Robert Schneider
Till Bartke

item.title: Near-ultraviolet photon-counting dual-comb spectroscopy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07094-9

We demonstrate a photon-counting approach that extends the unique advantages of spectroscopy with interfering frequency combs into regions where nonlinear frequency conversion tends to be very inefficient, providing a step towards precision broadband spectroscopy at short wavelengths and extreme-ultraviolet dual-comb spectroscopy.
item.dc:title: Near-ultraviolet photon-counting dual-comb spectroscopy
item.dc:creator: Bingxin Xu
Zaijun Chen
Theodor W. Hänsch
Nathalie Picqué

item.title: Disappearing cities on US coasts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07038-3

High-resolution vertical land motion and elevation datasets combined with projections of sea-level rise of 32 major US coastal cities shows that a considerable amount of land area, population, and properties are threatened by relative sea-level rise by 2050.
item.dc:title: Disappearing cities on US coasts
item.dc:creator: Leonard O. Ohenhen
Manoochehr Shirzaei
Chandrakanta Ojha
Sonam F. Sherpa
Robert J. Nicholls

item.title: Healable and conductive sulfur iodide for solid-state Li–S batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07101-z

A conductive, low-melting-point and healable sulfur iodide material aids the practical realization of solid-state Li–S batteries, which have high theoretical energy densities and show potential in next-generation battery chemistry.
item.dc:title: Healable and conductive sulfur iodide for solid-state Li–S batteries
item.dc:creator: Jianbin Zhou
Manas Likhit Holekevi Chandrappa

item.title: Anomalous electrons in a metallic kagome ferromagnet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07085-w

Laser-based micro-focused angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy reveals both fractionalized and marginal quasiparticles in C3-symmetric electron pockets near the Brillouin zone centre of the ferromagnetic kagome metal Fe3Sn2.
item.dc:title: Anomalous electrons in a metallic kagome ferromagnet
item.dc:creator: Sandy Adhitia Ekahana

item.title: A vagal reflex evoked by airway closure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07144-2

A specific neural reflex of the vagus nerve is identified that induces gasping in response to airway closure.
item.dc:title: A vagal reflex evoked by airway closure
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schappe
Philip A. Brinn
Narendra R. Joshi
Rachel S. Greenberg
Soohong Min
AbdulRasheed A. Alabi
Chuchu Zhang
Stephen D. Liberles

item.title: East-to-west human dispersal into Europe 1.4 million years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07151-3

Burial-dating methods using cosmogenic nuclides indicate that the oldest stone tools at Korolevo archaeological site in western Ukraine date to around 1.4 million years ago, providing evidence of early human dispersal into Europe from the east.
item.dc:title: East-to-west human dispersal into Europe 1.4 million years ago
item.dc:creator: R. Garba
V. Usyk

J. D. Jansen

item.title: Integrated frequency-modulated optical parametric oscillator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07071-2

An integrated device that combines optical parametric oscillation and electro-optic modulation in lithium niobate creates a flat-top frequency-comb-like output with low power requirements.
item.dc:title: Integrated frequency-modulated optical parametric oscillator
item.dc:creator: Hubert S. Stokowski
Devin J. Dean

item.title: A concerted neuron–astrocyte program declines in ageing and schizophrenia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07109-5

A synaptic neuron and astrocyte program (SNAP) varies among healthy humans, may shape interindividual differences in synapses and plasticity, and is undermined in schizophrenia and with advancing age.
item.dc:title: A concerted neuron–astrocyte program declines in ageing and schizophrenia
item.dc:creator: Emi Ling
James Nemesh
Melissa Goldman

item.title: Synthetic reversed sequences reveal default genomic states
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07128-2

Introduction of a long synthetic DNA into yeast genomic loci results in high default transcriptional activity in yeast but low activity in mouse, suggesting distinct default levels of genomic activity in these organisms.
item.dc:title: Synthetic reversed sequences reveal default genomic states
item.dc:creator: Brendan R. Camellato
Ran Brosh
Hannah J. Ashe
Matthew T. Maurano
Jef D. Boeke

item.title: The hyphal-specific toxin candidalysin promotes fungal gut commensalism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07142-4

Both the yeast and hyphal forms of Candida albicans enable colonization of the mammalian gut, with hyphal cells secreting the toxin candidalysin to inihibit bacteria and support fungal commensalism.
item.dc:title: The hyphal-specific toxin candidalysin promotes fungal gut commensalism
item.dc:creator: Shen-Huan Liang
Shabnam Sircaik
Joseph Dainis
Pallavi Kakade

Richard J. Bennett

item.title: Buoyant crystals halt the cooling of white dwarf stars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07102-y

A population of freezing white dwarf stars maintaining a constant luminosity for a duration comparable with the age of the universe can be explained by a solid–liquid distillation mechanism interrupting cooling for billions of years.
item.dc:title: Buoyant crystals halt the cooling of white dwarf stars
item.dc:creator: Antoine Bédard
Simon Blouin
Sihao Cheng

item.title: Bumblebees socially learn behaviour too complex to innovate alone
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07126-4

Bumblebees can learn how to open a two-step puzzle box by observing another trained bee, indicating that these insects can use social learning to acquire a behaviour too complex to otherwise be learnt through individual trial and error.
item.dc:title: Bumblebees socially learn behaviour too complex to innovate alone
item.dc:creator: Alice D. Bridges
Amanda Royka
Tara Wilson
Charlotte Lockwood
Jasmin Richter
Mikko Juusola
Lars Chittka

item.title: Parental histone transfer caught at the replication fork
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07152-2

Structures of the yeast replisome associated with the FACT complex and an evicted histone hexamer offer insights into the mechanism of replication-coupled histone recycling for maintaining epigenetic inheritance.
item.dc:title: Parental histone transfer caught at the replication fork
item.dc:creator: Ningning Li
Yuan Gao

item.title: The Correctives
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00376-2

It’s just an illusion.
item.dc:title: The Correctives
item.dc:creator: Preston Grassmann

item.title: Will these reprogrammed elephant cells ever make a mammoth?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00670-z

The de-extinction company Colossal is the first to convert elephant cells to an embryonic state, but using them to make mammoths won’t be easy, say researchers.
item.dc:title: Will these reprogrammed elephant cells ever make a mammoth?
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Geologists reject the Anthropocene as Earth’s new epoch — after 15 years of debate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00675-8

But some are now challenging the vote, saying there were “procedural irregularities”.
item.dc:title: Geologists reject the Anthropocene as Earth’s new epoch — after 15 years of debate
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: The world must rethink plans for ageing oil and gas platforms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00645-0

Earth’s oceans are awash with ageing energy infrastructure. A change in the law is needed to ensure that these structures are decommissioned in ways that maximize environmental and societal benefits.
item.dc:title: The world must rethink plans for ageing oil and gas platforms
item.dc:creator: Antony Knights
Anaëlle Lemasson
Matthew Frost
Paul Somerfield

item.title: China has a list of suspect journals and it’s just been updated
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00629-0

Nature talks to the librarian behind China’s Early Warning Journal List about how it is compiled each year.
item.dc:title: China has a list of suspect journals and it’s just been updated
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Trump versus Biden: what the rematch could mean for three key science issues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00657-w

Depending on the winner of November’s election, researchers anticipate two completely different paths ahead for the environment, public health and more.
item.dc:title: Trump versus Biden: what the rematch could mean for three key science issues
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson
Natasha Gilbert
Max Kozlov
Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Nature publishes too few papers from women researchers — that must change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00640-5

This journal will double down on efforts to diversify the pool of corresponding authors and referees.
item.dc:title: Nature publishes too few papers from women researchers — that must change

item.title: Interactions between immune cells recorded
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00426-9

Direct interactions between cells in tissue are incompletely understood because the advanced technologies required to examine them are still in their infancy. A new method can decipher cell–cell interactions on a large scale.
item.dc:title: Interactions between immune cells recorded
item.dc:creator: Michael A. Wheeler

item.title: Landmark study links microplastics to serious health problems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00650-3

People who had tiny plastic particles lodged in a key blood vessel were more likely to experience heart attack, stroke or death during a three-year study.
item.dc:title: Landmark study links microplastics to serious health problems
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Oldest stone tools in Europe hint at ancient humans’ route there
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00627-2

Dating of artefacts found at a site in western Ukraine suggests that archaic humans had entered Europe’s eastern gate by 1.4 million years ago.
item.dc:title: Oldest stone tools in Europe hint at ancient humans’ route there
item.dc:creator: Giorgia Guglielmi

item.title: Mammalian cells repress random DNA that yeast transcribes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00575-x

In experiments dubbed the Random Genome Project, researchers have integrated DNA strands with random sequences into yeast and mouse cells to find the default transcriptional state of their genomes.
item.dc:title: Mammalian cells repress random DNA that yeast transcribes
item.dc:creator: Sean R. Eddy

item.title: Ancient skin sported intricately patterned scales
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00587-7

The discovery of 285-million-year-old fossils of intricately patterned animal scales indicates that evolutionary tinkering of armoured skin started at the dawn of life on dry land as aquatic vertebrates adapted for terrestrial survival.
item.dc:title: Ancient skin sported intricately patterned scales
item.dc:creator: Maksim V. Plikus

item.title: Why scientists trust AI too much — and what to do about it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00639-y

Some researchers see superhuman qualities in artificial intelligence. All scientists need to be alert to the risks this creates.
item.dc:title: Why scientists trust AI too much — and what to do about it

item.title: Bees and chimpanzees learn from others what they cannot learn alone
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00427-8

It has been argued that human culture rests on a unique ability to learn from others more than we could possibly learn alone in a lifetime. Two studies show that we share this ability with bumblebees and chimpanzees.
item.dc:title: Bees and chimpanzees learn from others what they cannot learn alone
item.dc:creator: Alex Thornton

Space and nuclear pioneers show the value of empowering women in STEM
item.dc:title: Space and nuclear pioneers show the value of empowering women in STEM

Soyeon Yi

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: New Mexico’s prehistoric pottery, and traces of the Ice Age

item.title: Why can’t researchers agree about consciousness? Because it’s all in the mind

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00632-5

Forget lung, breast or prostate cancer? Why we shouldn’t abandon tumour names yet
item.dc:title: Forget lung, breast or prostate cancer? Why we shouldn’t abandon tumour names yet
item.dc:creator: Albrecht Stenzinger
Frederick Klauschen

item.title: Well-matched vibrations cool electronic hot spots
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00529-3

Diamond layers can help to dissipate the heat generated by high-power semiconductor devices. This effect has now been enhanced by adding layers of materials and engineering their crystal-lattice vibrations to be compatible at the interfaces.
item.dc:title: Well-matched vibrations cool electronic hot spots
item.dc:creator: Liwen Sang

item.title: How five crucial elections in 2024 could shape climate action for decades
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00642-3

Some of the world’s biggest carbon emitters are going to the polls this year — the results could determine whether humanity can correct its trajectory of dangerous global warming.
item.dc:title: How five crucial elections in 2024 could shape climate action for decades
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty
Jeff Tollefson
Carissa Wong
Sarah Wild
Nisha Gaind

item.title: Meningitis could be behind ‘mystery illness’ reports in Nigeria
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00666-9

The WHO confirms three meningitis deaths, which it says might have triggered rumours of an outbreak of an unknown disease.
item.dc:title: Meningitis could be behind ‘mystery illness’ reports in Nigeria
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: Megafires are here to stay — and blaming only climate change won’t help
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00641-4

It’s not just global warming that’s driving the growth in destructive wildfires. Better land management is the first step to mitigating the risks.
item.dc:title: Megafires are here to stay — and blaming only climate change won’t help
item.dc:creator: Renata Libonati

item.title: Here’s what many digital tools for chronic pain are doing wrong
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00542-6

To address the chronic-pain crisis, digital health technologies must break out of their silos and become integrative and holistic.
item.dc:title: Here’s what many digital tools for chronic pain are doing wrong
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Lipp

item.title: Five tips for digitizing handwritten data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00646-z

Need to digitize field notes or historical documents? Researchers share their best practices.
item.dc:title: Five tips for digitizing handwritten data
item.dc:creator: Alla Katsnelson

item.title: Genetics solves mystery of rare brown pandas after 40 years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00614-7

Chinese researchers find the gene responsible for the brown-and-white fur of a handful of giant pandas in China.
item.dc:title: Genetics solves mystery of rare brown pandas after 40 years

item.title: Oldest known animal sex chromosome evolved in octopuses 380 million years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00637-0

Result reveals for the first time how some cephalopods determine sex.

item.title: Organoids grown from amniotic fluid could shed light on rare diseases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00656-x

Organ-like groups of cells can be grown from amniotic fluid samples and offer hope for studying congenital conditions.

item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: Millions of research papers at risk of disappearing from the Internet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00616-5

An analysis of DOIs suggests that digital preservation is not keeping up with burgeoning scholarly knowledge.
item.dc:title: Millions of research papers at risk of disappearing from the Internet

item.title: Big science in Latin America: accelerate particles and progress
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00598-4

item.title: My productivity waxes and wanes — and I’m learning to account for it
item.content:encoded:

Understanding that our bodies and minds are capable of variance day by day is an important step to becoming a more balanced scientist.
item.dc:title: My productivity waxes and wanes — and I’m learning to account for it

item.title: The spy who flunked it: Kurt Gödel’s forgotten part in the atom-bomb story
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00644-1

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00601-y

Evening skies, which are usually red after a volcanic eruption, were instead emerald after the 1883 event.
item.dc:title: Why sunsets were a weird colour after Krakatau blew its top

item.content:encoded:

A vaccine shortage and persistent sanitation problems threaten the success of the world’s first public vaccination campaign against dengue virus.
item.dc:title: Brazil's record dengue surge: why a vaccine campaign is unlikely to stop it

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 March 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00600-z
